head.title: Software Tells Wireless E-Mail To Please Get to the Point

hedline.hl1: Software Tells Wireless E-Mail To Please Get to the Point

abstract.p: Software company AmikaNow offers Web-based service that it says will automatically extract only most important sentences from long E-mail messages before passing them on to a wireless device (S)

block.p: Long e-mail messages are rarely welcome by busy computer users. But they can be almost unbearable when viewed through the tiny screens of wireless gadgets.
AmikaNow, a Canadian software company, now offers a service that it says will automatically extract only the most important sentences before passing them on to a wireless device.
Long e-mail messages are rarely welcome by busy computer users. But they can be almost unbearable when viewed through the tiny screens of wireless gadgets.
AmikaNow, a Canadian software company, now offers a service that it says will automatically extract only the most important sentences before passing them on to a wireless device.

''People want e-mail highlights,'' said Suhayya Abu-Hakim, the company's president and chief executive. AmikaFreedom.com is a Web-based variation of software the company has been selling for about a year.

To use it, users must fill out a long registration form to indicate, among other things, the address of their main e-mail servers. AmikaNow's servers copy e-mail messages as they arrive at customers' main mail servers. The software then does the chopping, first by selecting the most important sentences, then by further reducing them.
The software is largely based on artificial intelligence research by Dr. Abu-Hakim at the Canadian government's National Research Council.

Not all the decisions about cuts are made using complex algorithms. The first sentence is usually the first to go, Dr. Abu-Hakim said, because ''a lot of people begin e-mails with some nicety like 'it was good to see you again.' ''
By the company's estimate, the software has a success rate of 75 percent to 80 percent. That is partly because of the current software's limitations, Dr. Abu-Hakim acknowledged.
But she said there was another important factor: ''Not everyone writes well. In the case where the e-mail makes no sense and the writing is poor, the highlight is going to be poor.''
The service is currently free as it is still in development. Dr. Abu-Hakim said the company planned to start charging users $2 to $5 a month for the service by the end of the year.
